    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-sm-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="container"><div class="panel-pane pane-fieldable-panels-pane pane-vid-2131 pane-bundle-text pane-fpid-241 clearfix"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div class="fieldable-panels-pane">
    <div class="field field-name-field-basic-text-text field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div>
<div>
<div>
<div class="openberkeley-faq-hide-answer">
<div>
<h2><a name="ucb" id="ucb"></a>UC Berkeley Students</h2>
</div>
</div>
<div id="openberkeley-expand-all"><a href="#cc">Community College Students</a> | <a class="openberkeley-collapsible-collapse" href="#openberkeley-expand-all">collapse all</a> <a class="openberkeley-collapsible-expand" href="#openberkeley-collapsible-container-0-target">expand all</a></div>
<div class="openberkeley-faq-hide-answer"><!-- Close div: faq-qa-header -->
<div>
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">What is the American Cultures (AC) requirement?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>AC is a Berkeley campus requirement, the one course that all undergraduate students at Cal need to pass in order to graduate. The AC requirement introduces students to the diverse cultures of the United States through a comparative framework. Courses are offered in more than forty departments in many different disciplines at both the lower and upper division level.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Who needs to take an AC course?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>All students who entered Berkeley in fall 1991 or thereafter in lower division standing (as a freshman or sophomore with 0-55 transferable semester units), and all students who entered in fall 1993 or thereafter.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">I am a graduating senior with no time left and I just found out I need AC to graduate. What should I do? </a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>You can enroll in an AC course during summer session at U.C. Berkeley or a Community College, or through concurrent enrollment at a community college. Discuss your options with your academic advisor.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Can I take my AC course on a pass/not pass basis or do I need to take it for a letter grade?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>The AC requirement may be taken for either a letter grade of C- or better, or on a Pass/Not Pass basis.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">How do I find an AC course?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>There are two ways to find an AC course. You can access a list of current courses from the AC website or you can search the Online Schedule of Classes by typing "American Cultures" in the "additional information" box and using any other parameters you choose to narrow your search.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Are all approved AC courses at Berkeley offered on a regular basis?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>No. Just because a course is on the approved list of AC courses at Berkeley doesn't mean it will be offered again in the future. For current course offerings, please consult the Online Schedule of Classes or use the side navigation bar to access a list of AC courses for the current semester.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Should I try to take an AC course in my first semester?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>Many AC courses are offered each term, but they often have high demand and long waitlists. Although you don't have to take an AC course in your first semester, the best advice is to satisfy your AC requirement early.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Can I also use my AC course to satisfy a breadth requirement?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>Yes. Many AC courses also satisfy college and major requirements, in addition to satisfying the campus-wide AC requirement.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Do I have to take my AC course here at Berkeley? Can I take it online or at a community college?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>Yes, several community colleges offer courses that count towards the AC requirement. These courses are listed <span><a href="http://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/committees/amcult/approved-ac-courses-other-colleges" rel="noreferrer">here<span><span class="element-invisible">(link is external)</span></span></a></span>. Please always consult with an advisor in choosing community college courses.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">I know I passed an AC course at Berkeley, but my transcript still shows that I haven't satisfied the AC requirement. How can I fix this? </a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>If you passed an American Cultures course at Berkeley, go to 120 Sproul Hall, the Registrar's Office and fill out a correction form. If you passed an American Cultures course at a community college before transferring to Berkeley, go to 110 Sproul Hall, the Admissions Office.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">I've noticed that History 7B at Berkeley is an AC course. I took a course with the same course number at another college. Does this count for AC credit? </a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>It only counts if the course is listed as one of the approved courses at other colleges that satisfy the AC requirement. If not, then you would need to petition the AC subcommittee to determine if the course meets the criteria for AC. Unless the course meets very specific criteria outlined in the Academic Senate regulations, it probably doesn't satisfy the requirement. Currently the only History 7B course outside of UC Berkeley that satisfies AC is at Berkeley City College.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">I was told that History 7A at Berkeley has been an AC course since fall 1998. I took History 7A before this. Does the course I took count for AC credit?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>No. If you took the course prior to its being approved as an AC course, you would need to petition the AC subcommittee to determine if the course met the criteria for AC at that time, which is unlikely.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">I am an international student. Do I still need to satisfy the AC requirement?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>Yes, all students, including international students, need to satisfy the requirement.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Can I take a course that satisfies the AC requirement at a community college through concurrent enrollment?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>Yes, but first consult your academic advisor.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Do all AC courses have an AC suffix? </a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>No. Most AC courses have the AC suffix, but some do not. However the schedule of courses should indicate which requirements a course fulfills.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">I notice some courses (e.g. Sociology 3, Anthropology 3, American Studies 10) are sometimes offered with the AC suffix and sometimes without. Are both versions AC courses?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>No. Sociology 3AC is AC-approved, but Sociology 3 is not. The same goes for similar pairs of courses. For AC purposes, these pairs of courses are different. For most other purposes (college breadth requirements or major requirements), these pairs of courses are equivalent.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Is the AC requirement the same as the AH&amp;I requirements? </a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>No. The AC requirement is a campus requirement. The American History &amp; Institutions requirements are University requirements. However, students may take History 7A or 7B to satisfy both their AC and American History requirements. Students may take Political Science 1AC to satisfy both the AC and American Institutions requirement. Information about AH&amp;I can be found <a href="http://guide.berkeley.edu/undergraduate/colleges-schools/letters-science/american-history-institutions-requirement/" rel="noreferrer">Here<span><span class="element-invisible">(link is external)</span></span></a></h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">Where can I find out more information about other requirements I need to graduate?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>Undergraduate graduation requirements very depending on your major.  For more information on your specific requirements, visit your academic advisor.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container --> <!-- include subcategories --></div>
<!-- Close div: faq-dl-hide-answer -->
<p></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div></div>
  </div>

  
  </div>
<div class="panel-pane pane-fieldable-panels-pane pane-vuuid-83f15dbe-726c-47ea-940e-d9d649dec33d pane-bundle-text clearfix"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <div class="fieldable-panels-pane">
    <div class="field field-name-field-basic-text-text field-type-text-long field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div>
<h2><a name="cc" id="cc"></a>Community College Students</h2>
</div>
<p style="text-align:right"><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/ucb">UC Berkeley Students</a> | <a class="openberkeley-collapsible-collapse" href="#openberkeley-expand-all">collapse all</a> <a class="openberkeley-collapsible-expand" href="#openberkeley-collapsible-container-0-target">expand all</a></p>
<p></p>
<div><!-- list questions (in title link) and answers (in body) -->
<div>
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">At my previous college, I took a course that was about race and ethnicity in the US so I thought it was an AC course. My Info-BEARS report still shows that I haven't satisfied the AC requirement. Why not?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>If your course is not listed as one of the approved courses at other colleges that satisfy the AC requirement, then you haven't satisfied the requirement. Unless the course meets very specific criteria outlined in the Academic Senate regulations, it probably doesn't satisfy the requirement. If you believe the course meets those criteria, then you can submit a petition.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">As a community college transfer student, I satisfied the IGETC requirements. Does this mean I have automatically satisfied my AC requirement?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>No. Unless you specifically passed one of the approved courses at other colleges, you have not satisfied your AC requirement.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">I'm a transfer student. Do I have to complete the AC requirement in order to be admitted to Berkeley? </a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>No. AC is a graduation requirement, not an admission requirement. So you can satisfy this requirement after being admitted to Berkeley if you haven't already completed it at community college.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">How can I tell what community college courses satisfy Berkeley's AC requirement?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>Many California community college courses have been approved as satisfying AC. Go to <a href="http://assist.org" rel="noreferrer">assist.org</a>. Select University of California, Berkeley Select the year you're interested in, select a California community college, e.g., Berkeley City College Under "By Major," select &gt; "Information - American Cultures Graduation Requirement" The community college course(s) approved for satisfying the Requirement appear on the right side of the page.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">I know I passed an AC course at my Community College, but my transcript still shows that I haven't satisfied the AC requirement. How can I fix this?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>If you passed an American Cultures course at a community college before transferring to Berkeley, go to 110 Sproul Hall, the Admissions Office.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-container">
<h4 class="openberkeley-collapsible-controller"><span><a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/faq-page">My community college course is not listed on www.assist.org (link is external) or on the AC website, but I think it should satisfy Berkeley's AC requirement. Who should I contact?</a></span></h4>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-controller -->
<div class="openberkeley-collapsible-target">
<div>
<div>
<div>
<h5>If this is the case you can try petitioning the course for AC credit. The petition form is found<span> <a href="http://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/amcult_studentpetition_10.2016_0.pdf" rel="noreferrer">here<span><span class="element-invisible">(link is external)</span></span></a></span>. Instructions for petitioning are on the form, but you can email <span><a href="mailto:ac_center@berkeley.edu" rel="noreferrer">americancultures@berkeley.edu<span><span class="element-invisible">(link sends e-mail)</span></span></a></span> with questions.</h5>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-target --></div>
<!-- Close div: openberkeley-collapsible-container --></div>
</div></div></div></div></div>
  </div>

  
  </div>
</div>        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

</div><!-- /.boxton -->
  </div>
        </div>
      </div> <!-- /#main -->
    </div> <!-- /#content -->
          </div> <!-- /#main-content -->
</div> <!-- /#main-wrapper -->

        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2><span>Satisfying the AC Requirement at UC Berkeley</span></h2>
<p>American Cultures courses can be taken at any time during a student's undergraduate career at Berkeley, but we strongly urge students to meet the requirement as early as possible.  Students must receive a grade no lower than C- or P to satisfy the requirement. </p>
<p>For a list of courses that satisfy the AC requirement at UC Berkeley, please visit the <a href="http://classes.berkeley.edu/search/class/?f%5B0%5D=im_field_term_name%3A566&amp;f%5B1%5D=sm_general_requirement%3AAmerican%20Cultures" rel="noreferrer">UC Berkeley Classes website<span><span class="element-invisible">(link is external)</span></span></a>.</p>
<p>If you are looking for a list of approved American Cultures courses offered at UC Berkeley since 1991, please visit the <a href="http://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/committees/amcult/approved-ac-courses-berkeley" rel="noreferrer">Academic Senate's list</a>.</p>
<h2>Satisfying the AC Requirement at<span> Other Colleges</span></h2>
<p>AC courses may also be taken "off-campus" at a community college or a partner institution. For a list of approved courses, please visit the <a href="http://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/committees/amcult/approved-ac-courses-other-colleges" rel="noreferrer">Academic Senate's list</a>, or refer to assist.org. </p>
<h2>Petitioning a Course for AC Credit</h2>
<p>Students also may submit a petition form to the Academic Senate if they believe a specific course satisfies the American Cultures Requirement. </p>
<p>The AC curriculum has been specially developed to enrich the student experience at UC Berkeley, and as such, is a unique reflection of UC Berkeley faculty's expertise in fields related to issues of critical diversity studies. However, there are instances in which courses offered at other educational institutions also formulate experiences which meet the expectations of the AC requirement at UC Berkeley. In this case, students have the option of submitting a petition to the Academic Senate, to have a non-AC course they have taken and successfully passed, if they believe that course satisfies the AC requirement.</p>
<p>It is important to keep in mind, that just because a non-AC course "looks" or "feels” like an AC course this does not mean that a petition will be approved by the Academic Senate.  AC courses are governed by a very specific regulation that is interpreted and applied by the Academic Senate’s Subcommittee on the Breadth Requirement in American Cultures.</p>
<p>Please note, a separate campus entity, the Academic Senate Subcommittee, reviews all student petitions, not the AC Center.  Student petitions are rigorously reviewed, and the Subcommittee applies the highest standards of college-level course material, course readings, and analytical skills required for course assignments. Therefore, serious consideration should be given to the strength of a substitution request before an individual submits a petition.</p>
<p><strong>Basic Information</strong>: The AC Subcommittee meets once a month on Fridays during the fall and spring semesters. Student petitions must be received by 4 p.m. on the Friday before the scheduled meeting.</p>
<p>For a list of meetings, please visit <a href="http://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/committees/amcult/info" rel="noreferrer">http://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/committees/amcult</a>.</p>
<p>To download a petition form, please visit <a href="http://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/committees/amcult/amcult_studentpetition_10.2016_0.pdf" rel="noreferrer">http://academic-senate.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/committees/amcult/amcult_studentpetition_10.2016_0.pdf</a>.</p>
<p>All materials should be submitted directly to the Academic Senate in 320 Stephens Hall #5842. </p>
<p>Students will receive a written response from the Academic Senate within two weeks of the meeting when the petition was reviewed.</p>
<p></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

                                  </div>

          </div>
        </div>
      </div> <!-- /.navbar-header -->

      <!-- Collect the nav links, forms, and other content for toggling -->

<div id="main-wrapper" class="main-wrapper">
    <div id="pre-content" class="container">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12">
                  <div id="breadcrumb" class="visible-desktop">
            <h2 class="element-invisible">You are here</h2><div class="item-list"><ul class="breadcrumb"><li class="first"><a href="/home">Home</a></li>

<li class="last">Student Advisory Board</li>
</ul></div>          </div>
                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Student Advisory Board</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>About the Board</strong></p>
<p><span>The AC Student Advisory Board (ACSAB) is an opportunity for undergraduate students to serve as a bridge to the AC Center and the development of the American Cultures Engaged Scholarship (ACES) Program. The AC Student Advisory Board explores concrete issues pertinent to the experience of students as they complete the AC graduation requirement. In mutual support, the AC Center Director, Victoria Robinson, informs the board of relevant issues within the university as well as engages in a dialogue across campuses nationwide. </span></p>
<p>In the past, members of our ACSAB have assisted and participated in AC Center events such as student forums for our anniversary, pedagogical workshops for faculty to conider how to address racial diversity and discrimination in the classroom, as well as creating <a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/students/student-advisory-board/associated-students-uc-pass-senate-bill-25">ASUC Student Senate Bill 25</a> which secured funding for the ACES Program. </p>
<p><strong>Vision Statement</strong></p>
<p>The ACSAB aims to serve the University of California, Berkeley student community as a liaison between the American Cultures Center, the American Cultures Engaged Scholarship (ACES) Program, and the multiple UC Berkeley communities through transparent and efficient communication.  As a board, we will work towards continuously improving and reviewing both the American Cultures requirement and engaged scholarship component that inspires to make the theoretical practical for whom it wishes to serve. <span>We aim to:</span></p>
<ul><li>Build pedagogy intended to engage the foundations of the AC curriculum to current campus climate and community engaged scholarship.</li>
<li>Evaluate and assess the opportunity of growth of the American Cultures Center, current courses/prospective courses, that are held accountable to the lived experiences of marginalized communities.</li>
<li>Facilitate the opportunities to create safe spaces for critical and transparent dialogue with campus administration (including but not limited to: Chancellor, the Vice Chancellor of Equity &amp; Inclusion, Undergraduate Education, Multicultural Student Development Offices, Critical Dialogues Across Differences (CDAD), Multi-Cultural Center (MCC), etc)</li>
<li><span>Cultivate the sustainability and expansion of this board in order to advocate for our respective student body.</span></li>
</ul><p>Please visit, <a href="https://docs.google.com/a/berkeley.edu/forms/d/1syK_WxztMjHgc57W3TSGglEpgQ7MmRQMhegU-V9raG4/viewform" rel="noreferrer">our application form</a> to apply to be a member.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>

</div><!-- /.boxton -->
  </div>
        </div>
      </div> <!-- /#main -->
    </div> <!-- /#content -->

    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12">
                  <div id="breadcrumb" class="visible-desktop">
            <h2 class="element-invisible">You are here</h2><div class="item-list"><ul class="breadcrumb"><li class="first"><a href="/home">Home</a></li>

                          <div class="page-title">
            <div class="container">
              <h1 class="title">Associated Students of UC Pass Senate Bill 25</h1>
            </div>
          </div>
                <div id="page-header">
                                      </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div> <!-- /#pre-content -->
    <div id="main-content" class="container">
        <div id="content" class="col-md-9 col-md-push-3">
      <div id="main" class="main" role="main" tabIndex="-1">
        <div id="main-inner">
            <div class="region region-content">
    
<div class="panel-display boxton clearfix radix-boxton" id="page-page">

  <div class="container-fluid">
    <div class="row">
      <div class="col-md-12 radix-layouts-content panel-panel">
        <div class="panel-panel-inner">
          <div class="panel-pane pane-node-content"  >
  
      
  
  <div class="pane-content">
    <article class="node node-openberkeley-content-page clearfix">

  
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h4><strong>Associated Students of the University of California Pass Senate Bill 25</strong></h4>
<p>Last Fall, the Associated Students of the University of California, Berkeley passed Senate Bill (SB) 25 in Support of Public Education and the ACES Program.  SB 25 focuses on the value of undergraduate students learning both within the classroom and engagement with local and regional communities. You may <a href="https://americancultures.berkeley.edu/sites/default/files/a_bill_in_support_of_public_education_sb25.pdf">download a PDF</a> copy or read the bill in its entirety below:</p>
<p></p>
<div><span>Associated Students of the University of California</span></div>
<div>Fall 2013 SB 25</div>
<div>A Bill in Support of Public Education and the ACES Program</div>
<div> </div>
<div><strong>Authors: </strong><span>Pavan Upadhyayula (Senator, ASUC) and Destiny Iwuoma (Senator, ASUC)</span></div>
<div><strong>Sponsors: </strong><span>Pavan Upadhyayula (Senator, ASUC) and Destiny Iwuoma (Senator, ASUC), Eric Wu (Senator, </span><span>ASUC), Emily Truax (Senator, ASUC)</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, the mission statement of the UC system states “The distinctive mission of the University is<span>to serve society as a center of higher learning, providing long-term societal benefits… and provide other </span><span>kinds of societal benefit”</span><sup>1</sup><span>, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, UC Berkeley was founded as a marriage of a Land-grant public institution and a<span>state run institution with the purpose of advancing generations and the communities of </span><span>California</span><sup>2</sup><span>, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, in the wake of budget problems increasing amounts of funding are coming from private <span>institutions and tuition, instead of from state funding and this challenges the core of what it means to be a </span><span>public institution,</span><sup>3</sup><span> and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, as public institutions search for their roots regarding their public character, it is increasingly <span>important for educators and systems of education to understand the democratic potential of education </span><span>rooted in a culture of questioning and personal experience</span><sup>4</sup><span>, and</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, the practices of a public institution should be concerned foremost with the lived experience <span>and empowerment of the majority of students who define this campus, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, our education should not strictly have knowledge as an end goal, but instead should use <span>partnerships with local communities that produce knowledge through the shared experience of students </span><span>and community members, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div><span>WHEREAS, understanding education through this community engaged scholarship manifests itself in the </span><span>following ways:</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>1) scholarly investigation of real-life social problems or public issues;</div>
<div> </div>
<div>2) real-life social problems and research to address these problems that are <span>defined with or by the community;</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>3)community-university partnerships that are collaborative and reciprocal and <span>have shared authority in defining success;</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>4) knowledge to solve or improve public issues that is collaboratively developed <span>by universities and communities;</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>5) the utilization of institutional resources and knowledge to solve these real-life <span>social problems; and</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>6) community-engaged research or projects that are related to and forward faculty <span>members’ research and teaching.</span><sup>5</sup></div>
<div> </div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, prioritizing these learning outcomes is necessary for students to become active leaders <span>capable of change instead of acquiescence in the face of structural inequality, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, the American Cultures Requirement was voted on by the student body, and established in <span>1989 and has required all students since 1991 to fulfill this requirement for graduation, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, the American Cultures requirement has allowed students to grapple with complex social <span>problems relating to racial inequality and justice-oriented scholarship,</span><sup>6</sup><span> through a research-led </span><span>environment, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, the American Cultures Engaged Scholarship (ACES) program has provided upwards of 30 <span>courses that “engage students in community-based learning”<sup>7</sup>, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, this program has been funded exclusively from private sources through a grant from the <span>Evelyn and Walter Haas Jr. Foundation,, without any institutional funding from the University,</span></div>
<div>
<div> </div>
<div>
<div>WHEREAS, the program operated on a budget shy of 900,000 dollars over a five year period and was <span>still able to create over 30 courses ranging across many departments and create lasting partnerships with </span><span>local communities,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, the cost of creating additional programs is 7,000 dollars and once running these courses are <span>often self-sufficient through the community they connect students to, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, through its tenure ACES has achieved numerous benchmarks in achieving specific learning <span>outcomes and goals by incorporating community within education and has improved the quality of </span><span>research and knowledge the students come away with after a course, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, incorporating this pedagogy in all departments provides promising avenues for more realworld <span>research, and greater depth of learning for all students, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>WHEREAS, the ACES program model has been adopted by other institutions of higher learning <span>such as Stanford due to its remarkable success in achieving statistically significant increases in </span><span>learning outcomes related to participatory citizenship, justice-oriented citizenship, and structural </span><span>thinking about racial inequality, and,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, the ASUC encourages UC Berkeley to fully fund and <span>institutionalize the ACES Program and provide for its expansion in coming years, and</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that AAVP Jameson draft a letter to admin and faculty, namely the <span>Vice Provost for Teaching, Learning, Academic Planning and Facilities, the incoming Executive Vice </span><span>Chancellor and Provost and the American Cultures Academic Senate Chair, outlining the stance taken </span><span>herein by students,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>THEREFORE BE IT RESOLVED, that EAVP Mecklai reach out to other student bodies of public <span>institutions and start a conversation regarding how this model can become actively incorporated as a core </span><span>of nationwide public education.</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>THEREFORE BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED, that President Pepito correspond with Chancellor <span>Dirks regarding the ACES program and its future funding on Campus,</span></div>
<div> </div>
<div>THEREFORE BE IT FINALLY RESOLVED, that the ASUC recognizes the ACES model as a <span>forward-thinking and organic approach to public education that should be brought to all departments on </span><span>campus.</span></div>
</div>
<div> </div>
<div><span style="text-decoration:underline">_________________________________________________________</span></div>
<div><sup>1</sup><a href="http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/aboutuc/missionstatement.html" rel="noreferrer">http://ucop.edu/uc-mission/index.html</a></div>
<div><sup>2</sup><a href="http://www.berkeley.edu/about/hist/foundations.shtml" rel="noreferrer">http://www.berkeley.edu/about/hist/foundations.shtml</a></div>
<div><sup>3 </sup><a href="http://articles.latimes.com/2011/aug/22/local/la-me-college-pay-20110822" rel="noreferrer">http://articles.latimes.com/2011/aug/22/local/la-me-college-pay-20110822</a></div>
<div><sup>4 </sup><a href="http://chronicle.com/article/Lessons-From-Paulo-Freire/124910/" rel="noreferrer">http://chronicle.com/article/Lessons-From-Paulo-Freire/124910/</a></div>
</div>
<div><sup>5 </sup>Gordon da Cruz, C. (2013). Critical democratic citizenship: The effects of community-engaged <span>scholarship and inequality content on student learning.</span></div>
<div><sup>6 </sup>Gordon da Cruz, C. (2013). Critical democratic citizenship: The effects of community-engaged <span>scholarship and inequality content on student learning.</span></div>
<div><sup>7</sup><a href="http://diversity.berkeley.edu/aces" rel="noreferrer">http://diversity.berkeley.edu/aces</a></div>
<div> </div>
<div> </div></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
</article>
  </div>

  
  </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
